body:
Also here: 

https://travis-ci.com/github/playframework/playframework/jobs/488391572#L3280-L3285

Now on another file, but same new scripted tests
Nothing to worry about, I will increase the timeout to fix that.
I guessed it was a timeout issue, but I was wondering why we don't see it in other tests. Isn't the timeouts just the same as in other scripted tests?

Which other tests do you mean? I can just talk about the `dev-mode-compile-and-config-error-source` test:
https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/2a43f632191e2fbc9b4557f25fe80424f2c9073a/dev-mode/sbt-plugin/src/sbt-test/play-sbt-plugin/dev-mode-compile-and-config-error-source/test#L53-L63
It seems 2 seconds sometimes (but no always) is just too low to give the app time to re-compile.
I think if we increase all the timeouts in these test to like 4 or 5 seconds we should be fine.
I will fix that with one of the upcoming pull requests.
There are similar tests that test recompilation, no?

I added scripted tests

- `dev-mode-compile-and-config-error-source`
- `dev-mode-runtime-error-source`

for both of them I will increase _all_ the timeouts in their `test` file.

Not sure if it's the same (I don't know how to find the actual test failures in the Play build), but dev-mode-compile-and-config-error-source failed in https://travis-ci.com/github/playframework/playframework/jobs/489354615
@patriknw It's the same. I am increasing the timouts in #10655 to fix that problem.

issue.title: Run scripted tests on sbt 1.4.x + refactoring

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
As [suggested once by Dale](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/pull/9936#pullrequestreview-334442852) I now folded `scripts/test-scripted-13x` into `scripts/test-scripted`. I also can not see why we should have different scripts for different sbt versions... Also because this pull request now adds another sbt version,1.4.9, meaning the scripted tests will now be run against ~1.2.x,~ 1.3.x and 1.4.x.

I also defined fixed sbt versions in `.travis.yml`. Before that the job(s) that "_Run scripted tests (a/b/c) for sbt 1.x_" would just use the sbt version set by interplay (See [Line](https://github.com/sbt/sbt/blob/v1.4.6/main/src/main/scala/sbt/ScriptedPlugin.scala#L63) -> [Line](https://github.com/playframework/interplay/blob/3.0.0/src/main/scala/interplay/PlaySbtBuildBase.scala#L14) -> [Line](https://github.com/playframework/interplay/blob/3.0.0/src/main/scala/interplay/Versions.scala#L9)). IMHO setting the versions hardcoded in .travis.yml is more readable (took me a while to figure out the default comes from interplay), safer (what if interplay upgrades to 1.3.x or newer, but nobody updates the `.travis.yml` description, when looking at the tests someone may still thinks that the tests are running for 1.2.x) and also easier to maintain (we can quickly test new sbt versions by just updating .travis.yml instead of releasing and upgrading interplay).
